reporter_caption.center: CAMPBELL v. CHICAGO BURLINGTON QUINCY R. CO., 314 Ill. App. 384 (1942)

center.bold: Herschel H. Campbell, Appellee, v. Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad

court.center: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District.

opinion.syllabus:
AUTOMOBILES AND MOTOR VEHICLES, § 208[fn*] — railroad crossingcollision; sufficiency of evidence. In the second trial of an action to recover damages for personal injuries sustained by plaintiff as a result of a collision between his automobile and a freight train at a railroad crossing, the weight of the evidence was that the bell rang, the whistle sounded and the headlight was burning, and a verdict for plaintiff was against the manifest weight of the evidence.
[fn*] See Callaghan's Illinois Digest, same topic and sectionnumber.
opinion.posture:
Appeal from Superior Court of Cook county; Hon. E.I. FRANKHAUSER, presiding.
Affirmed. Heard in first division, first district, this court at October term, 1941.
opinion.opinion_text: "Not to be published in full." Opinion filed April 20, 1942.
